article_title: Despite the stakes, some voters will sit out this election
article_text:
Despite the stakes, some voters will sit out this election

Stephanie Harrison knows Tuesday's election is important. She knows she wants to have a voice and cast a ballot, but she also knows from experience that there's a good chance she won't make it to her polling place.

article_metadata.description: Only slightly more than a third of eligible Texans decided who would be governor in 2010, which made Texas the state with the worst turnout rate in the country.  Texas has stood at the rear guard of the nation's voter turnout rates for decades, and experts say the state's politics feature nearly every factor associated with low turnout.  Things are different in the states with the best rates of voter turnout, says Regina Lawrence, director of the Annette Strauss Institute for Civic Life at the University of Texas.  Research has shown that Texas has the second-least politically competitive federal elections in the nation, which could depress turnout by a few percentage points.  Experts also say the lack of competition feeds another reason Texans do not vote: belief that it won't make a difference.  [...] in spite of his political background, he says he may not appear in a voting booth Tuesday.  Nobody this year is a really great, authentic leader, he said before turning to the Texas governor's race as an example.  Democratic groups hoping to change that are banking on a rising Latino voice that shifts the state's political center to the left.
article_metadata.author.name: By Abe Levy and Theodore Schleifer, San Antonio Express-News
